channel.title: Event | Dr. Luz Angélica Caudillo Mata

item.title: AI Demo Showcase Panel
item.description:
This panel was held as part of the technical program of the 4th International Meeting of Artificial Intelligence and Its Applications (RIIAA) .

Role:

  • Co-organizer

Abstract:

The AI demo showcase session features demos from across different areas of AI. This session is particularly focused on showcasing the power of state-of-the-art AI technology being applied to different domains, such as robotics, speech, and predictive coding. The session provides a lens into how AI is transforming our world for the benefit of humankind.

item.title: LatinXperiences Workshop
item.description:
This workshop was one of the accepted diversity and inclusion activities at the AAAI-21 conference.

Roles:

  • Co-organizer
  • Facilitator

Abstract:

LatinXperiences is an event that strives to create new and lasting connections between established researchers, at top-tier universities and research laboratories, and early-career researchers and students from Latin American countries.

There are thriving research and tech communities in Latin America that, for the most part, do not interact with the AAAI community. Our goal is to bring these communities together in a welcoming, social environment.

item.title: Panel Making a Career Transition Into Industry: Stories & Tips from Math, CS, and Stats Alumni
item.description:
This panel was celebrated as part of the Career & Innovation Hub Program co-organized by the Banff International Research Station (BIRS) and other leading Canadian Mathematical institutions.

Roles:

  • Organizer
  • Facilitator
  • Speaker

Abstract:
In this panel, alumni of graduate programs in mathematics, computer science, and statistics share how they successfully transitioned from academia into industrial positions in the areas of machine learning, AI, and data science. After learning from the story of each of our four panelists, we’ll have an extensive Q&A session.

item.title: Women in Industry With a STEM Background Panel
item.description:
This panel was held as part of the Diversity in Mathematics: Undergraduate Women’s Summer School organized by the Pacific Institute of the Mathematical Sciences (PIMS).

Roles

  • Organizer
  • Speaker
  • Facilitator

Abstract
The purpose of this panel is to show participants of the summer school the diverse applications and paths that a STEM degree leads to.

item.title: Foro: Experiencias de Contratación y Re-incorporación
item.description:
Foro celebrado como parte del programa de la 4ta Reunión de Matemáticos Mexicanos en el Mundo.

Role:

  • Co-organizer

Resumen:
Foro para intercambiar opiniones en temas relacionados a experiencias de contratación y re-incorporación de científicos mexicanos a instituciones de investigación mexicanas.

item.title: Panel en Intercambio, Mobilidad y Reincorporación
item.description:
Panel celebrado como parte del programa de la 4ta Reunión de Matemáticos Mexicanos en el Mundo.

Role:

  • Co-organizer
  • Faciliator

Resumen:
Panel centrado en discutir temas relacionados a intercambio, mobilidad, y reincorporación de científicos mexicanos en áreas matemáticas.

item.title: Open Source Software in the Geosciences Panel
item.description:
This panel was held as part of the technical program of the 2017 American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

Role:

  • Co-organizer

Abstract:
This panel discusses open-source software and explore its interaction with the wider scientific community: What are motivating factors for developing open-source software? What are examples of its impacts?

There are questions about the implementation and functioning of an open-source community: How do developers engage with the community? How are new contributors/users on-boarded? What lessons can you offer to those who are involved in other open-source initiatives?

Attribution for software contributions is an immature topic that is particularly important for early-career scientists and relevant to tenure track, hiring, and proposal review panels. How should the scientific community recognize these contributions?

Wrestling with these questions is perhaps one of the main reasons why open-source products are still relatively rare; we explore these questions in the panel discussion.
